comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think this photo is much earlier than 1896, and shows the original James Barnet designed building under construction in the late 1870s. See the scaffolding going through the windows, and the lack of statues. The building was completed in 1880, so imho this is before 1880. See - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=5045423 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Secretary's_Building . Barnet's design was based on the Palazzo Farnese in Rome. There are heaps of photos of this building in State Records at various stages of additions. This one is the earliest, then in chronological order (I hope) - Original James Barnet Building (c.1880) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... Walter Liberty Vernon additions - Phillip St extension, mansard roof and dome (c.1895) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... With electric street lamp (post 1904) - almost identical - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Charles Bayliss photographed the completed (outside) building in 1879 for a Sydney Exhibition Album from the same position on the Government House gatehouse. So this photo is well before 1879

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] A pretty compelling argument especially when you compare the other images you've linked to titled as "construction of the dome" which show the statues in place and scaffolding only on the roof of the building. The surrounding landscape is also significantly different. There are footpaths, tram lines and the background is a lot more built up in investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... as compared to this image. -AG

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's an interesting T&CJ news item on the external statues at the Col Sec's building (mid way down second highlighted column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13675831 Note how in investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... the top statue on the Bridge/Phillip St corner isn't yet in place...just going on the T&CJ item, I'd say this would have been the space 'Art' occupied as from 13 January 1888.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The external statues on the Colonial Secretary's building were created by the Italian-born Sydney sculptor Achille Simonetti (1838-1900). The statues occupying the niches on the Macquarie/Bridge St corner were the first to be added. Macquarie/Bridge St (3 statues) : 'Mercy' (upper level); 'Justice' (middle); 'Wisdom', aka 'Minerva' (lower)...'Justice' was the first to be added, on 9/11/1878; 'Mercy', appears to have been added between ca. September 1879-June 1880 (date to be established...but possibly in ca. September 1879); 'Wisdom' was the last to be added, ca. 15/12/1880. Phillip/Bridge St (3 statues) : 'Art' (upper); 'Science' (middle); 'Labour' (lower)...of this group, 'Labour' was the first to be added, some time after June 1881 (date remains to be established); 'Science' was added on 27/10/1883; 'Art' was added on 13/1/1888 SOURCES: SMH November 1878...'Justice' added 9/11/1878 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13417133 ; SMH March 1879...clay model for 'Mercy' just completed (4th item in highlighted column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13431900 ; SMH 16/8/1879 indicates that 'Mercy' was either completed or nearing completion...that it was to be placed in position in ca. 10 days time - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13439487 ; SMH September 1879...this confusing article appears to indicate 'Mercy' had been completed, but not yet added (2nd last item, 2nd highlighted column)...notably, this item has the positions of the statues mixed up... - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13448304 ; SMH June 1880 - item on the Colonial Secretary's Building...provides background on the statues...by this time 'Mercy' appears to have been added - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13461488 ; SMH October 1880...per this item, 'Mercy' and 'Justice' were on display in the New South Wales court at the 1880 Melbourne International Exhibition...(mid way down column 1) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13470462 ; however, going on this pic, I suspect these would have been Simonetti's plaster casts rather than the finished stone statues - museumvictoria.com.au/collections/itemimages/367/560/3675... ; SMH Dec 1880...'Wisdom' aka 'Minerva' added (4th item, 2nd highlighted column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13484085 ; and also - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13472561 ; SMH January 1881...Simonetti commissioned to execute the 3 Phillip/Bridge statues - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13483439 ; SMH June 1881...indicates that 'Labour' was then a clay model - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13489243 ; Queenslander November 1883...'Science' added on 27/10/1883 (last item in highlighted section) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article19794356 ; also see this T&CJ item - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71005351 ; SMH 14/1/1888...'Art' added the previous day - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13675831 Maybe as more newspapers are digitised, other reports of statues being placed in position might emerge which will enable us to establish a few dates more precisely... James Barnet's papers (held at USYD) might also shed some light on a few dates sydney.edu.au/arms/archives/barnet.shtml This pic shows all the Macquarie/Bridge St niches empty...presumably this pic was taken before 'Justice' was placed in position on 9/11/1878...and also after the scaffolding had been removed (see comment below) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=412558 These pics show an empty niche for the lower Macquarie/Bridge St statue ('Wisdom' aka 'Minerva')...per the above, these pics would have been taken between ca. September 1879, when we at least know 'Mercy' was completed, and ca. 15/12/1880, when 'Wisdom' was added - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=412560 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=412559 This pic shows an empty niche for the upper Phillip/Bridge St statue ('Art')...per the above, this pic would have been taken in the 4 plus year interval between the addition of 'Science', on 27/10/1883 and the addition of 'Art', on 13/1/1888 - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] ; [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Of course, in addition to things such as renovations, or the addition of statues, clock faces and other embellishments, scaffolding is another feature which might be used to date photos...this item from the T&CJ, 27/10/1877, indicates that the scaffolding around the external walls of the Colonial Secretary's Building had then been removed...I gather fairly recently...(rhs column, 1st misc. item) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70610016...if we can believe the T&CJ, this puts the date of this SRNSW pic at pre ca. mid October 1877... (!) Then...this item from the SMH, 30/6/1876, indicates the second story of the Col Sec's Building was then under construction (towards end of 2nd highlighted column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13376071 ...given the advanced state of construction shown in this SRNSW pic, I'd say it was taken some time afterwards...late 1876 or well into 1877. (!!) Going on this item from the SMH, 9/3/1877, which indicates that the facade of the top story was still in progress, I'd say we're looking at 1877...and presumably after March 1877 (1st highlighted columnm 2nd item) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13389591 ...given we can't see how things looked from the other side, we can't be too emphatic...but at this point I'd opt for a date range of ca. March-October 1877.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Phew! There's enough for a thesis there. Winter 1877 is looking good, particularly from the long midday shadow of the Treasury Building on the right.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5452983 note how this 1878 Illustrated Sydney News pic shows a full house of statues in the Phillip/Bridge St niches...but I suspect this is a case of artistic license, as it doesn't stack up with the various dates which can be established via the digitised newspapers...but it's intriguing nonetheless...you'd think that if artistic license was involved, the ISN artist might have also placed a few statues in the vacant niches on the Lands Office Building. If you're a 19th century Sydney building spotter, there are some interesting images in this Illustrated Sydney News special issue...
